Award.AwardTitle: Stress Corrosion Micro-Cracking or Static Fatigue: The Principal Cause of Rate Effects and "Aging" in Sand

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Time and rate effects in sands affect both the short- and long-term behavior of earth structures, yet understanding of the causes of that behavior is lacking. A hypothesis is suggested that makes use of the process of micro-fracturing of the microscopic morphological features on grain surfaces to explain the nature of time effects in sand. The new approach this research is taking makes it potentially transformative. Experimental observation techniques based on Scanning Electron Microscopy and Atomic Force Microscopy will be employed to produce visual evidence for time-delayed micro-fracturing of asperities on grain surfaces (static fatigue), whereas micro- and macro-loading tests will be used to gain quantitative evidence. The scientific merit of this research is in its creative and original concept exploiting the multi-scale approach to explain the puzzling time-related effects in sand. The engineering relevance of this research is that the time-dependent behavior of soils can have important consequences on design and long-term behavior of earth structures and on soil-structure interaction (for instance, the load on retaining structures can increase in time as a result of the time-dependent nature of sand behavior).

The impact of this research will affect areas beyond geotechnical engineering, e.g., space exploration missions, which require predictions of surface mobility, planning of drilling operations, and processing of the Lunar/Martian regolith. Due to the absence of water and atmosphere, Lunar regolith grains have a rich surface morphology, a characteristic central to the hypothesis in this research. This research promotes a new concept, advances discovery, and promotes learning.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
A hypothesis was suggested regarding the causes of time effects in silica sand. Time and rate effects in sands affect both the short- and long-term behavior of earth structures, yet the understanding of the causes of that behavior is lacking. This hypothesis makes use of the process of fracturing of the microscopic morphological features on grain surfaces to explain the nature of time effects in sand. Experimental observation techniques based on Scanning Electron Microscopy and Atomic Force Microscopy were employed to produce visual evidence for time-delayed micro-fracturing of asperities on grain surfaces (static fatigue), whereas testing at the grain scale was carried out to gain quantitative evidence. The scientific merit of this research is in its creative and original concept exploiting the multi-scale approach to explain the puzzling time-related effects in sand.

A visual evidence for damage to individual asperities caused by loading of inter-granular contacts is illustrated in Figure 1. While a substantial portion of this damage occurs at the time of contact loading, the fracturing continues in time at constant load, producing delayed response, often referred to as creep. A measurement of the time-dependent response of a contact to sustained load of 0.7 N is illustrated in Figure 2. The delayed response is most intense immediately after the load is applied, but it has a decaying effect, and the convergence of the two grains stops after about 18 days. This process was modeled using distinct element method, where an individual sand grain was modeled as an assembly of solid sub-particles chemically bonded together. Fracture was then simulated as time- and load-dependent bond damage. A model of a half-grain in contact with a rigid plate is shown in Figure 3, whereas Figure 4 illustrates a small contact region between two silica grains; a web of force chains is shown in the neighborhood of the contact (each grain represented by a region of 30 x 30 x 15 microns). Immediately after a load of 2.4 N was applied, the load was transferred through 10 contact points, and there were 88 cracks (damaged bonds) that developed as a result of the load application (these are illustrated by small red or blue discs). In 20 days, the number of contact points between the two grains increased to 31, and the number of damaged bonds increased to 2,670. This time-dependent damage process is considered to be the cause of time effects and aging in silica sand, and it is essential to the static fatigue hypothesis advocated in this research. 

The engineering relevance of this research is in its consequences on design and long-term behavior of earth structures and on soil-structure interaction. The impact of this research can affect areas beyond geotechnical engineering, for instance, space exploration missions, which require predictions of surface mobility, planning of drilling operations, and processing of the lunar/Martian regolith. Due to the absence of water and atmosphere, lunar regolith grains have a rich surface morphology, a characteristic central to the hypothesis advocated in this research. This research promotes a new concept, advances discovery, and promotes learning.


Last Modified: 09/21/2015
Modified by: Radoslaw L Michalowski

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A hypothesis was suggested regarding the causes of time effects in silica sand. Time and rate effects in sands affect both the short- and long-term behavior of earth structures, yet the understanding of the causes of that behavior is lacking. This hypothesis makes use of the process of fracturing of the microscopic morphological features on grain surfaces to explain the nature of time effects in sand. Experimental observation techniques based on Scanning Electron Microscopy and Atomic Force Microscopy were employed to produce visual evidence for time-delayed micro-fracturing of asperities on grain surfaces (static fatigue), whereas testing at the grain scale was carried out to gain quantitative evidence. The scientific merit of this research is in its creative and original concept exploiting the multi-scale approach to explain the puzzling time-related effects in sand. A visual evidence for damage to individual asperities caused by loading of inter-granular contacts is illustrated in Figure 1. While a substantial portion of this damage occurs at the time of contact loading, the fracturing continues in time at constant load, producing delayed response, often referred to as creep. A measurement of the time-dependent response of a contact to sustained load of 0.7 N is illustrated in Figure 2. The delayed response is most intense immediately after the load is applied, but it has a decaying effect, and the convergence of the two grains stops after about 18 days. This process was modeled using distinct element method, where an individual sand grain was modeled as an assembly of solid sub-particles chemically bonded together. Fracture was then simulated as time- and load-dependent bond damage. A model of a half-grain in contact with a rigid plate is shown in Figure 3, whereas Figure 4 illustrates a small contact region between two silica grains; a web of force chains is shown in the neighborhood of the contact (each grain represented by a region of 30 x 30 x 15 microns). Immediately after a load of 2.4 N was applied, the load was transferred through 10 contact points, and there were 88 cracks (damaged bonds) that developed as a result of the load application (these are illustrated by small red or blue discs). In 20 days, the number of contact points between the two grains increased to 31, and the number of damaged bonds increased to 2,670. This time-dependent damage process is considered to be the cause of time effects and aging in silica sand, and it is essential to the static fatigue hypothesis advocated in this research. The engineering relevance of this research is in its consequences on design and long-term behavior of earth structures and on soil-structure interaction. The impact of this research can affect areas beyond geotechnical engineering, for instance, space exploration missions, which require predictions of surface mobility, planning of drilling operations, and processing of the lunar/Martian regolith. Due to the absence of water and atmosphere, lunar regolith grains have a rich surface morphology, a characteristic central to the hypothesis advocated in this research. This research promotes a new concept, advances discovery, and promotes learning. Last Modified: 09/21/2015 Submitted by: Radoslaw L Michalowski
